docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who tried to breathe during last week's hot spell is unlikely to quarrel with the need to begin imposing tougher auto-emissions testing. New Jersey has the second worst air pollution problem in the nation. Our air is unhealthy at least once every three days during the summer. While much of the problem is caused by pollution drifting east from coal-burning power plants in the Midwest, public health experts say that at least one-third of the state's pollution problems are caused by emissions from its five million cars.

headline.main: Taking a Deep Breath Before Debate on Emissions

docs.abstract: Jennifer Preston column on plan by New Jersey to award stricter auto-emissions testing program to only bidder, Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Connecticut Republicans unanimously nominated Gov. John G. Rowland for a second term today at a convention that was carefully scripted to send a message very different from those of previous years: This is not your father's Republican Party. In a marked departure from the 1994 convention, there was almost no talk of repealing the income tax that was enacted in 1991 or dismantling the state government, issues that caused deep splits among Connecticut Republicans in the past.

headline.main: Rowland Is Renominated As G.O.P. Tests New Turf

docs.abstract: Connecticut Republicans nominate Gov John G Rowland for second term; convention in Hartford is short on calls for repealing income tax and dismantling state government; speakers dwell on host of other issues--rebuilding state universities, expanding Medicaid and revitalizing cities--that have often been considered Democratic turf; photos (M)

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: THE coupons arrived by the handful when Janlori Goldman was pregnant with her daughter, and she couldn't figure out how the companies knew she was expecting. There were coupons for parenting magazines, baby announcements, diapers and children's book clubs. ''I started to wonder,'' she said. ''Where are they getting this information? Is the hospital selling it? Is my doctor making it available?'' She never got an answer, but to Ms. Goldman, the questions were of more than passing interest. As the founder of the Health Privacy Project at Georgetown University, her goal is to raise the public's awareness about the erosion of medical privacy. It has been an uphill battle. ''Privacy,'' Ms. Goldman said, ''has not always been a top-line issue.''

headline.main: The Nation: The Numbering of America; Medical I.D.'s and Privacy (Or What's Left of It)

docs.abstract: Article examines consideration by Clinton Administration--following 1996 Congressional mandate--to assign every American health-care identification number that could be used to create giant electronic data base capable of tracking everyone's medical records from cradle to grave; just how information would be used and who would have access to it remains unclear; even though 35 states have enacted laws intended to protect privacy of patients, there are no Federal protections (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was upsetting enough when her nanny quit to go work for another family, but what shocked Carroll Bogert was the salary used as a lure: $800 a week, plus health insurance. ''I did think the sum was rather stunning,'' said Ms. Bogert, a Manhattan mother of two whose job as a spokeswoman for Human Rights Watch requires a lot of traveling. ''She'd worked for us for two and a half years, and we paid what I thought was the rather princely sum of $550.''

headline.main: Show Nanny the Money; As Economy Booms, Pay Rise for Child-Care Workers

docs.abstract: Nannies in New York City and its pricier suburbs are commanding higher salaries and better benefits thanks to strong economy, which expands their job opportunities while putting more money at disposal of many parents; city's millionaires may be able to pay a premium nanny up to $1,000 a week after taxes, but the merely prosperous are being priced out of the market for even an average nanny; parents in Greenwich are outraged to learn that a family new to town promised a nanny that the car she would use--and helped pick out--would be hers if she stayed two years; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Peary became aware of a wooden feeling in his feet. When Henson ripped off the sealskin boots he saw that the explorer's legs were bloodless white to the knee. As he tore off the undershoes, two or three toes from each foot clung to the hide and snapped off at the joint. ''My god, Lieutenant!'' he cried. ''Why didn't you tell me your feet were frozen?''

headline.main: Going Where A Lot of Other Dudes With Really Great Equipment Have Gone Before

docs.abstract: John Tierney article on sledding and skiing across Ellesmere Island with a group of other desk jockeys stung by the adventure-travel bug; says such pseudo-exploration is all part of rising tide of 'explornography,' which like pornography provides vicarious thrills of exploring without the risk of actually having to venture into terra incognita; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Turning to a popular election-year issue, the House today passed a contentious Republican bill that would expand the rights of millions of patients who are dissatisfied with their medical care. The Republican bill is more limited than what Democrats want, and the White House said President Clinton would probably veto it.

headline.main: House Passes a Patients Bill; Veto Is Likely

docs.abstract: House passes contentious Republican bill that would expand rights of millions of patients who are dissatisfied with their medical care; bill is more limited than what Democrats want, and White House says Pres Clinton would probably veto it; bill would guarantee coverage of emergency medical care in certain cases, allow consumers to appeal decisions to independent board, assure that doctors can share information with their patients and permit women to go directly to obstetricians and gynecologists; bill also has two provisions White House and Democrats vigorously oppose: allowing businesses to band together to buy insurance, and reducing number of uninsured by expanding use of medical savings accounts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House said tonight that President Clinton would probably veto the version of ''patient protection'' legislation that Republican leaders plan to take up in the House of Representatives on Friday. Mr. Clinton described himself as a champion of patients' rights. But in a formal evaluation of the House Republican bill, the White House said, ''It covers too few people, it provides too few patient protections, and it contains unnecessary and irrelevant provisions that undermine the chances for a bipartisan agreement on a patients' bill of rights.''

headline.main: White House Says Veto of 'Patient Protection' Bill Is Likely

docs.abstract: White House says that Pres Clinton will probably veto version of 'patient protection' legislation that Republican leaders plan to take up in House on July 24 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 1,200 state legislators who gathered in this desert gambling mecca this week for the annual meeting of the National Conference of State Legislatures had the look of winners. They were flush with money, their state treasuries overflowing with record tax receipts generated by the booming national economy.

headline.main: Political Briefing; Basking in a Golden Glow, State Legislators Welcome More Responsibility

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Health Identifier for All Americans Runs Into Hurdles'' (front page, July 20): As a lawyer I am appalled at the suggestion that patients should blindly trust health insurers and others with private information. The most protective measure for the public would be a law requiring that a patient consent form be signed before any medical information is released.

headline.main: How to Sue Your H.M.O.; Protect Patient Privacy

docs.abstract: Letter from Marie Cappuccio, responding to July 20 article, says she, a lawyer, is appalled at suggestion that patients should blindly trust health insurers and others with private medical information (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH Congressional Democrats and Republicans jockeying fiercely for the high political ground on patients' rights, there is a good chance that efforts to clamp down on managed medical care abuses will come to naught this year. But it's a sure bet that at least one issue of contention -- the right to sue health maintenance organizations for malpractice -- will be back on Congress's agenda very soon. For one thing, the quarter-century-old bar to suits against medical insurers is, on its face, outmoded because managed care virtually guarantees that insurers as well as doctors have a role in choosing treatment. For another, the shield is apt to be breached anyway, as frustrated judges look for ways to hold H.M.O.'s accountable.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Battle over right to sue H.M.O.'s isn't going away.

docs.abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on proposal by Jeffrey O'Connell and James Neale for hastening settlement of malpractice suits, both in traditional doctor-patient litigation and those arising from managed care; says it seems inevitable that malpractice liability will be extended to managed care providers; drawing (M)
